Award.AwardTitle: Mechanism of Non-coding RNA Involvement in Transcriptional Gene Silencing

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: The process of gene expression requires the synthesis of ribonucleic acid (RNA), which works as an intermediate (messenger RNA or mRNA) between genes and proteins. Interestingly, there are also many other classes of RNA which do not encode proteins, known as non-coding RNA. One of the most mysterious classes of non-coding RNA has been proposed to be a major factor contributing to the regulation of gene activity by controlling transcription (i.e., the rate of mRNA synthesis). The goal of this project is to resolve the molecular mechanisms used by non-coding RNA to regulate gene activity in a process known as transcriptional gene silencing. This research will use unique tools available with the model plant organism Arabidopsis thaliana to specifically eliminate a class of non-coding RNA. This manipulation, along with several other genetic, biochemical and genomic approaches, will be used to explain how non-coding RNA guides specific silencing factors to DNA. Experiments will also determine if the molecular mechanism of non-coding RNA function in transcriptional gene silencing is conserved throughout the genome, or if many independent gene-specific mechanisms exist. Overall, the project will provide a better understanding of how genes are regulated.

Broader impacts: The project integrates various levels of undergraduate teaching to inspire the next generation of scientists. It involves a revision of a large-enrollment undergraduate course in genetics, the design of a specialty course focused on the general area of this research, and direct involvement of undergraduate students in this research. Additionally, the project will benefit society by advancing our understanding of the basic mechanisms of life and by providing a foundation that could contribute to future improvement of crop plants.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit. The goal of this project was to elucidate the role of non-protein coding RNA molecules (ncRNAs) in transcriptional gene silencing. It focused on a plant-specific specialized RNA polymerase known as Pol V. We obtained substantial insights into two aspects of ncRNA functions – mechanisms needed to recruit chromatin modifying factors and locus-specificity of RNA-mediated silencing mechanisms.

We determined mechanisms used by ncRNA to recruit chromatin modifying enzymes. We found that ncRNA is critical for a stepwise recruitment of at least three silencing factors, which together lead to the establishment of DNA methylation. We also found that ncRNA may indirectly recruit an ATP-dependent chromatin remodeling complex, which has been proposed to affect nucleosome positioning on its target loci.

We also found that the molecular mechanism of ncRNA-mediated silencing is remarkably universal throughout the genome with very limited locus specificity. However, genome-wide identification of ncRNA production and protein binding to ncRNA identified possible mechanisms regulating non-coding transcription. Moreover, it identified non-coding transcription as a possible key factor determining the boundaries between silenced transposable elements and active regions of the genome.

Broader impacts. The project integrated three levels of undergraduate education. The PI revised a large enrollment class to include the most recently discovered aspects of RNA biology, which are not yet covered in the available textbooks. The PI designed and taught a specialty course, which allowed the participants to build in depth understanding of topics related to this project. The project also provided hands on lab experience for several undergraduate and graduate students as well as two postdoctoral fellows. The outcome of the project will also benefit the society by advancing our understanding of the basic mechanisms of life.
